# Toepads 

Toepads are modified pads on the tips of the toes and fingers of many species of Asterophryinae frogs that help with clinging. Arboreal species have the most developed and largest toepads, whil some species (particularly fossorial or burrowing species) may have hardly and visible toepad. 

Here are some photos that we took under a dissecting scope and 32x and with 6x magnification by the camera. 

Frogs also use different postures with their toepads depending on lifestyle. Whereas arboreal and scansorial frogs often have them flat against the surface (like suction cups), terrestrial and fossorial species often have them flexed (@fig-toeposture). 

::: {#fig-toeposture layout-ncol=2}

![scansorial _Cophixalus variabilis_](images/Cophixalus_variabilis.jpg)

![fossorial _Xenorhina arboricola_](toepads/xenorhina_arboricola.jpg)

Note how the arboreal species holds their toepads flat against the surface whereas terrestrial and fossorial species sometimes flex them on their finger tips
:::


# _Austrochaperina_ (semi-aquatic)

::: {#fig-austrochaperina layout-ncol=3}

![_Austrochaperina palmipes_](toepads/buyetai/Austrochaperina_palmipes_537_buyetai_IMG_1701.jpg)

![Finger pad](toepads/buyetai/Austrochaperina_palmipes_finger_IMG_0658.jpg)

![Toe pad](toepads/buyetai/Austrochaperina_palmipes_toe_IMG_0659.jpg)

Toepads of a semi-aquatic species with well-developed toepads. It is from Buyetai, Normanby Island, PNG.

# _Choerophryne_ (scansorial)

::: {#fig-choerophryne layout-ncol=3}

![_Choerophryne sp. 2_ "fast clicker"](toepads/cliffside/Choerophryne_sp.2_fast_clicker_body_IMG_1262.jpg)

![Finger pad](toepads/cliffside/Choerophryne sp.2_finger_IMG_0632.jpg)

![Toe pad](toepads/cliffside/Choerophryne sp.2_toe_IMG_0634.jpg)

Toepads of a scansorial species with well-developed toepads. Many arboreal and scansorial species have larger finger pads than toe pads. It is from Cliffside camp, Kamiali on the EPCT of the mainland.
::: 


# _Cophixalus_

## _Cophixalus desticans_ (terrestrial)

::: {#fig-cophixalus layout-ncol=3}

![_Cophixalus desticans_](toepads/buyetai/Cophixalus desticans 613_buyetai_IMG_1900.jpg)

![Finger pad](toepads/buyetai/Cophixalus desticans complex sp.1_finger_IMG_0618.jpg)

![Toe pad](toepads/buyetai/Cophixalus desticans complex sp.1_toe_IMG_0619.jpg)

Toepads of a small terrestrial species with not well-developed toepads. It is from Buyetai, Normanby Island, PNG.
:::

## _Cophixalus verrucosus_ (scansorial)

::: {#fig-cophixalus layout-ncol=3}

![_Cophixalus verrucosus (a)_](toepads/buyetai/Cophixalus verrucosus 586_buyetai_IMG_1842.jpg)

![Finger pad](toepads/buyetai/Cophixalus verrucosus complex sp.2_finger_IMG_0615.jpg)

![Toe pad](toepads/buyetai/Cophixalus verrucosus complex sp.2_toe_IMG_0616.jpg)

![_Cophixalus verrucosus (b)_](toepads/buyetai/Cophixalus verrucosus 588_buyetai_IMG_1852.jpg){fig-align="left"}

Toepads of a scansorial species with clear toepads. Though the same genus as _Cophixalus desticans_, it has a very different lifestyle, requiring well-developed toepads. Species vary in coloration, as presented. It is from Buyetai, Normanby Island, PNG.
:::

## _Cophixalus cheesmanae_ (scansorial)

::: {#fig-cheese layout-ncol=3}

![_Cophixalus cheesmanae_](toepads/cliffside/Cophixalus cheesmanae 470_cliffside_IMG_1204.jpg)

![Finger pad](toepads/cliffside/Cophixalus cheesmanae complex sp.2_finger_IMG_0635.jpg)

![Toe pad](toepads/cliffside/Cophixalus cheesmanae complex sp.2_toe_IMG_0636.jpg)

_Cophixalus cheesemanae_ is a scansorial _Cophixalus_ often found on palms and even banana fronds. It is a good climber. From Cliffside camp, Kamiali, mainland Papua New Guinea. 
:::

# _Barygenys_ (fossorial)

::: {#fig-barygenys layout-ncol=3}

![_Barygenys sp._](toepads/cliffside/Barygenys_sp._473_cliffside_IMG_1336.jpg)

![Finger pad](toepads/cliffside/Barygenys sp_finger_IMG_0629.jpg){#fig-barygenysfing}

![Toe pad](toepads/cliffside/Barygenys sp._toe_IMG_0630.jpg)

_Barygenys sp._ is a small fossorial (burrowing) species. It is really hard to see toepads as this is a small species. The contrast has been adjusted here to see the slight difference in skin texture. From Cliffside camp, Kamiali. 
:::

# _Callulops_ (fossorial)

::: {#fig-callulops layout-ncol=3}

![_Callulops personatus_](toepads/cliffside/Callulops_personatus_352_cliffside_IMG_0684.jpg)

![Finger pad](toepads/cliffside/Callulops_personatus_finger_IMG_0654.jpg){#fig-callulopsfing}

![Toe pad](toepads/cliffside/Callulops_personatus_toe_IMG_0656.jpg){#fig-callulopstoe}

_Callulops personatus_ is a large fossorial (burrowing) species. It is one of the largest of all Asterophryinae. It is hard to see toepads, there may be some modified skin that blends into the rest of the toe. From Cliffside camp, Kamiali. 
:::
